O'REILLY'S ELIXIR OF LIFE.
[Being an Authentic Account of the Greatest Discovery of
the Century.]

William Henry James O'Reilly
Was a scientist of note.
He was known the whole world over
By the able books he wrote.
Why, his monograph on why the
Tails of cats are without eyes
Filled all lands with consternation,
With amazement and surprise.
Was he satisfied to linger
O'er the laurels he had won?
.Should ambition cease its soaring,
• When its flight had just begun ?
No! The goal of his desires
Was but bounded by the stars!
So as hard as ever William
Henry worked among his jars.

No. 9

Or that, rather, all who took it
(How the news rang in their ears I)
Would be younger than they were before
By five-and-twenty years.
Lean and sour-visaged spinsters
Who had passed full two-score, ten,
Took his mixture by the bottle
And were gay young girls again.
"Pore an' lonely widder ladies"
Almost lost their heads from joy.
They imbibed it by the gallon
And again were maidens coy.
Widowers with five wives buried
Hemmed and hawed, and said that they
Had no very strong objections
To continue on their way.
While the bachelors in hundreds
Could be seen at each drug store.
There was not a man among'em
But who took a case or more.

Worked! Why never in the history
Of mankind was there known
Such untiring activity
As that which he had shown.
He forgot to eat ; forgot to sleep ;
(Forgot to pay his rent.)
When at last his work was over
Then the news was broadcast sent.

Jimmie Jones—how can I tell it I —
Saw a bottle on a shelf—
Took it down and took a swallow,
And no longer was himself,
And that night when all the family
Sat o'erwhelmet1 with grief and fears,
In their midst a whisper sounded :
"Will be back in fifteen years."

Cities thrilled with mad excitement ;
Men discussed it on the cars ;
Papers spoke of it by pages.
It was telegraphed to Mars.
Exultation seized the people ;
Loud rejoicing filled the air ;
Till Professor James O'Reilly's
Hat grew too small for his hair.

Everything was topsy-turvy;
Naught was as it used to be.
You would find a mother's daughter
Who was older far than she.
Fathers, turned to beardless striplings,
Were more youthful than their sons.
Ah, through what a maze of marvels
This most truthful history runs!

For the wily James O'Reilly
Had discovered, it was said,
An elixir which would almost
Bring to life again the dead ;

Young folks had no show whatever.
These"made-over" beaux and belles
Took things firmly by the handle
And ran all to suit themselves.

2

THE NEWSLETTER.
Some young men who got disgusted
With such life, just stepped aside ;
Took a nip—evaporated!
Fin de siecle suicide.
I could tell to you forever
Of the marvels that were wrought;
Of the wondrous and astounding things
Which thus to pass were brought.
But I have a fear that someone
(Who don't know me)'11 say that I
Am just verging into danger
Of relating you a lie.
HERBERT KAUFMAN.

THE LEVERING LECTURES.

The Levering lectures are the gift of Mr.
Eugene Levering of Baltimore, the founder of
of the University Y. M. C. A. They are given
under the auspices of the Association in Levering Hall, and are intended specially for the
students of the University. They are not sermons, but they must be on topics distinctively
religious. The course has been in existence
since 1890 and now presents quite a respectable list of eminent men. They are :
1890. Rev. Dr. John A. Broadus of Southern
Baptist Theological Seminary.
1891. President W. R. Harper of Chicago
University.
1892. Rev. Dr. Richard R. Storrs of Brooklyn.
1893. Rev. Dr. William R. Huntington of
New York.
1894. President David J. Hill of the University of Rochester.
1895. Professor William R. Ramsey of the
University of Glasgow.
1896. Bishop J. H. Vincent of the M. E.
Church.
1897. Rev. Dr. Lyman Abbott of Brooklyn.
Francis Landley Patton, D. D., LL. D., the
lecturer for this year, was born in Bermuda in
1843. He received his education in Canada,
was actively engaged as a Presbyterian minister for sixteen years, and taught in the Pres-

byterian Theological Seminary at Chicago,
and later at Princeton. He was for three
years editor of The Interior, a leading Presbyterian paper published at Chicago. He became President of the College of New JersgY,
now Princeton University, in 1888, which
office he now holds.

GEOLOGICAL SPECIFIENS.

The Geological Department has just received a series of large specimens of massive
and crystallized albite, through the kindness
of Mr. W. Robinson Molinard of this city.
These specimens were taken from a large mica
mine situated about one mile north of Amelia
Courthouse, Amelia County, Va., where they
were found in a large geode during the working of the mine. They represent only a small
part of the mineral "pocket" which carried
iron pyrites, mica, garnets, corundum, fluorite
and different varieties of feldspar.
This particular "pocket," in which the albite
occurred projecting into the cavity in well-individualized crystals, is only a local development in a large lens of feldspar approximately
125 inches long by 20 inches wide, which
itself is very much like the pegmatite dikes
that are so well exposed about Baltimore, especially in the neighborhood of Orange
Grove.
The different crystals of the specimens often
show marked milky coloring or the iridescent
play of colors, which increases the value of the
specimens. The various crystals have not
been studied, but will no doubt serve as a subject of investigation for some member of the
Geological Department.

THE NEWS-LETTER was very much flattered
a short time ago by a request from a girls'
school for a copy of our paper as a model for
one they are preparing to issue. Bless them,
we wish them all the luck in the world, and
hope ere long to get some valuable points
from them !

NEWS OF A FORTNIGHT.
SENATE.

The Senate is busily preparing for forensic
battle, under the skilled leadership of the Censor, who has gained his experience in actual
contests in days gone by. A mock fight during
the last assembly served to display the valor of our stoutest champions. Their brilliant conduct on the field of "Liberty and
Equality" found its reward in the promotion
to higher honors. The general has placed in
their hands the banner of the Senate, to be
carried through the lines of the House in irresistible onslaught—or else to be covered with
the bodies of the defendants. Six Senators
are the champions-elect, viz: Senators Fisher
(leader), Stearns (secretary of war), Hubner,
Ulman, Ballard and Dieffenbach. A ministry
of war is planning the campaign, and training
the men. It consists of Senators Hodges
' (chief), Kennard (secretary) and Clarke. At
the next meeting of the Senate Champions
Fisher and Hubner will appear in a rotary
turret of points on the immigration question.
As they are confident that the missiles of fourteen assailants cannot penetrate this structure,
they will stay content with peeping at the
enemy through the loopholes.
HOUSE.

The House of Representatives met Wednesday, February 2. Mr. Censor made a few important announcements pertaining to the joint
debate. In brief, he said that the question
selected for the joint debate, "Resolved, That
further immigration to the United States
should be restricted," would be debated for
three consecutive meetings in the House ;
that two of the six selected debaters would
present points for the affirmative side, while
the House would argue against these and present additional points. The board of advisers
will record points brought forward by the
House.
At. the next session Speaker French and
Congressman Fisher will present points on
the affirmative, and one-third of the House

will argue against them. This method, as it
will be very general and searching, is practically for the purpose of getting the attitude of
the class as a whole toward the question.
The regular debate was : "Resolved, That
all men are free and equal." The affirmative
side was presented by Congressmen Knapp,
Bruce and Raymond; the negative by Congressmen Kurrelmeyer, Wright and RobinThe debate was quite lacking in dash
and spirit. The preparation that the debaters
gave the question was far too little for them
to arrive at any clear and definite idea of the
subject matter. This confusion of ideas was
also quite apparent in the open discussion.
The negative side won the debate through a
little better presentation, though no superiority of arguments.
The debaters from the class of '99 and the
advisers have taken active steps in preparation
for the joint debate. They are holding frequent meetings, in which they discuss the
question and criticise each other's style of
delivery.
The class of '99 met Wednesday, February
2. The class history was read and a few important points discussed.

THE STUDENT VOLUNTEER CONVENTION.

A notable event in inter-collegiate affairs
for this month will be the Student Volunteer
Convention, which will be held at Cleveland,
Ohio, beginning February 23. These conventions are held once in a generation of students and are attended by delegates from all
the colleges and universities of the country.
Unusual interest is being shown this year, and
the convention will be the largest ever held.
Four hundred institutions will be represented
by between 1,5oo and 2,000 students. Mr. F.S.
Brockman, Traveling Secretary of the Student Volunteer Movement, addressed the Y.
M. C. A. at its last meeting and urged that
Hopkins be well represented. The Secretary
announces that we will be represented by at
least two delegates.

The house-warming to be given on Thursday night in celebration of the opening of the
new cage and gymnasium, should be well supported by all members of the University. The
expenses of the occasion are to be met by the
undergraduate body, who will act as the hosts.
All men connected with the University are invited, and it is to be hoped that many of them
will attend. The "new era in our athletics,"
so much talked of and prophesied, could not
be better inaugurated than by making this occasion a great success. It is especially desirable that the men from the Medical School,
whose connection with the rest of the University is figuratively as well as literally "remote,"
should be well represented ; and to them in
particular a most cordial invitation is extended.

At last! Despite his anxious fears, the senior
has been rewarded. The hard-fought battles
of his freshman and junior years have not been
in vain ! He has seen his desire upon his
enemy
How he did enjoy it, with mouth and eyes

all open 1 And even the imperturbable grad.
was seen to smile a faint smile before turning
to his book again. The elevator boy's eyes
shone, and the postman waxed reminiscent.
The whole University seemed on the eye of
doing something, and the Dean
It was a noble fight, a royal scrap, a—but
words fail us. We all know just what it was,
and we all enjoyed it. What could have been
more deliriously exhilarating than to watch
that squirming mass of arms and legs? What
matters it if a few cheeks or shirts were torn,
a few hats or ribs stove in, a few buttons or
temper lost ? Think first of the pleasures it
gave; of the bookworn student who had not
had a hearty laugh since Christmas — then
strike the balance.
We must confess that we thought the old
pot social something of a failure. There was
the same wild abandon, the same noble heroism, the same melodramatic effect. But who
saw it? Only a few lucky seniors, pinned
close against the walls of a stuffy locker-room.
It was a purely selfish institution, born to crush
unseen and waste its rudeness on the dusty air.
Its sphere was too limited. It lacked a raison
d'art'. It gave pleasure to no one—except,
perhaps, the tailor.
But it's different now. We have an amphitheatre big enough for a bull-fight. There is
room for all the University, and half the town
besides. Send the faculty a special invitation
and let the ladies have reserved seats. Then
charge an admission fee for all the rest, and the
coffers of the Athletic Association will overflow.
It would be by far the most popular show in
town. And why? Is it because we are barbarous enough to hunger for the sight of
blood. Not at all. We would not have a single man hurt. We only feel more intensely
that same sense of delight which the immortal
Puck must have experienced that midsummer
night when he exclaimed : "Lord ! What
fools these mortals be !"

Certain writers of late have given considerable attention to the subject of city noises and

their effect upon mortality. We are assured
that some sweet day all doors will slam to a
set tune, and rumbling drays will sing a lullaby. However that may be, it occurs to us
that an investigation of the effect of noises
upon mentality at this University might prove
interesting. We have the finest general assortment of noises to be found anywhere in the
city. Our own little Ross street enjoys an
enviable reputation for its storminess and consequent popularity among all the drivers in
town. Car-gongs, mingled with street cries
galore, show no respect for Greek syntax or
economics? But, in addition to all these, we
take pleasure in announcing that a new noise
is in our midst. One of our neighbors to the
west has stocked his back yard with a lusty
flock of geese, and these sacred birds can reproduce at any time of the day all the "atmosphere" or "local coloring" the classical students can desire, who wishes to bring back the
time when Rome was so miraculously preserved.
THE NEWS-LETTER here solemnly promises
that it will devote its first earnings to the
purchase and exportation of those geese, and
then, if anything is left, it may think about cementing Ross street.

PROF. RILEY'S SUCCESS.

Among the recent Hopkins graduates who
have already achieved distinction is Dr. F. L.
Riley, professor of history at the University of
Mississippi. Since taking his degree here in
1896, Dr. Riley has been very energetic in his
efforts to promote the study of history in Mississippi, atld has endeavored, by addresses and
by articles in the newspapers and magazines,
to increase the interest of the public at large in
the subject. He served as secretary of the recent State Historical Association and took a
very prominent part in the proceedings of that
body. Dr. Riley is now trying to secure financial assistance from the State to publish the
papers, etc., of the Association.
About thirty of the graduate students in
chemistry enjoyed a trip to the Maryland
Steel Works at Sparrows' Point on Friday,
January 28. Dr. Charles L. Reese took the
boys down, and, with the assistance of Mr.
Reese, his brother, who is superintendent of
the works, explained the workings of the big
machinery.
All the fellows enjoyed the trip immensely
and both Dr. Reese and Mr. Reese have the
warmest thanks of those who were fortunate
enough to be able to accept their kindness.

The Universities of Indian Territory, Arizona, Honolulu and Sacarappa have adopted
the following regulations :
We can run ourselves without these little
colleges and high schools like Harvard and
Yale interfering.
No man shall play on the same team with
his grandson.
Children under five shall not be eligible for
college football teams.
Games in which we are licked shall be called
practice games.
Summer ice-polo shall be discouraged.
Rough football shall be stopped by ruling
out any player who touches another.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
ATHLETICS.
OPENING OF THE CAGE.

A large body of students, professors and
alumni listened to the speeches at the official
opening of the new gymnasium and cage.
President Gilman, Mr. Morton Stewart, Dr.
Renouf, the Dean, Dr. Read, Mr. Morrison,
Mr. Maddren and Mr. Scholl ('98) all spoke
on subjects pertaining to some feature of
physical development. The most noteworthy
speeches were beyond a doubt those of Dr.
Renouf, the director of the gymnasium, and
Mr. Morrison, the well-known lawyer and
Hopkins alumnus. They dwelt on the past
history of Hopkins athletics, and of gymnasium work in particular. It is well known
among all the students that fraternity rivalry
made the gymnasium unfashionable and
ruined our teams. Compulsory gymnasium
work will create a broader college spirit
through bringing all the students in closer
communication.
This first step towards
breaking,up our clanishness will also be the
dawn of a new and more prosperous era for
our athletics. Dr. Read gave an interesting
talk on mountain climbing, in which he called
attention to the fact that most of the noted
mountaineers are or have been university
men. Mr. Maddren spoke in the interest of
the lacrosse team, pleading for strict obedience to the captain.

CINDER TRACK NEEDED.

It is quite necessary that a cinder track
should be put in the cage. The candidates
for the track team cannot be properly trained
without it.
This track (as was stated by someone who
has experience in such matters) can be completed inside of seven days. It will not interfere with baseball or lacrosse, as it will be but
five feet broad ; on the other hand, it will afford opportunity for members of the above
mentioned teams to exercise their leg muscles
and get some wind.

HOCKEY.

The hockey team was defeated Tuesday of
last week by the University of Maryland. This
defeat puts Hopkins in third place, and makes
her chances for winning the championship
rather slim. The game was rough, several
men on both sides receiving bad cuts. Hopkins showed a decided lack of team work and
put up a slow game. The final score was :
University of Maryland 2, Johns Hopkins
University o.

ATHLETIC NOTES.

Mr. William M. Mackdermott has kindly
consented to train the track team. Mr. Mackdermott has had much experience, both as a
runner and trainer, and good results may be
looked for from this branch of athletics.
The gymnasium was opened Monday last.
Freshmen will be compelled to attend Dr.
Crenshaw's classes on Mondays, Wednesdays
and Fridays, and a record of attendance will
be kept. Tuesday and Thursdays are the days
appointed for seniors and juniors.
The class of '98, at a meeting held last Friday, decided to immortalize itself by placing
andirons in the fire-place of the smokingroom and a class shield on the wall. Messrs.
Fowler, V. E. Smith and Ulman were appointed a committee, with full power to make the
selections and assess the class the amount necessary for the purchases. Messrs. Ballard,
Harwood and Hodges were elected to the
House Committee of the gymnasium.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
THE GArIE OF GOLF.

The game of golf differs in so many essential
characteristics from other outdoor games that
at first sight it does not recommend itself to
the inter-collegiate athlete. In the first place,
unless a spectator has some personal interest
in a match, or is himself an enthusiast, golf is a
very slow game to watch. This would not suit
the average college "rooter." Again, the
rules absolutely forbid any noise—that is, talking, etc., during a stroke. College yells, which
have become a part and parcel of inter-collegiate games, would, therefore, have to be
abandoned. Further, golf differs from most
games in the fact that there is no personal contact, and consequently no man-to-man rivalry.
This would do away with the rigorous training
now so generally in vogue, as physical
strength per se is of no particular advantage,
but skill is the important factor. Many a time
have I seen some stalwart footballer, or cricketer, downed on the links by a man perhaps old
enough to be his father, or, again, by some slip
of a boy, simply because of the same skill.
It is often asked: "What is the attraction
about golf ?
Volumes could be written on
this subject. Perhaps our answer might be,
the fascination of hidden difficulties, the apparent ease with which a skillful player swings
his club and the real difficulty of attaining that
same skill. The infinite variety, for in no two
rounds of the links is a player confronted with
the same difficulties, might also be mentioned.
But the real attraction, to my mind, is that it
takes an honest gentleman to really play and
appreciate the game. And herein lies the chief
difference between this and other games. We
Americans are so bound down by rules and
umpires and reform, etc., that generosity to an
opponent and sport for sport's sake hardly get
a chance. In a match at golf each man is his
own umpire, and if any cheating and sly shifting of the "lie" of the ball, any miscounts,
creep into the golfer's record, all interest in
the game is at once lost.
Therefore, I think that inter-collegiate golf
is a most excellent thing, and deserves the attention of all true sportsmen, inasmuch as it

7

may serve to eradicate the spirit of "win by
hook or by crook" which so pervades our
American sports.
A.J. H. U. GOLFER.

EXCHANGES.

The Minnesota Magazine for January contains a well-written article on the Johns Hopkins University. It is written from a liberal
standpoint, and gives the Hopkins full credit
for the many excellent points so well known
to all her sons.
A well-deserved tribute is paid to President
Gilman for his ability and good judgment,
which have been so powerful in making our
University what it is—the first in America.
The author gives a brief account of the
foundation of the University, and then proceeds to a statement of the broad and liberal
policy which has always characterized the
management of the Hopkins.
Altogether, the article is one most satisfactory to Hopkins men. All the advantages and
good points are brought out in a manner
highly satisfactory.
One great fault is mentioned, and that is
one we all feel. It is the lack of college spirit
in the University. How long shall Hopkins
men allow this one fault to mar every account
of the University? Men, we can remove the
one great blot if we will ! Shall we not do it?

Dry as Pommery her eyes
When we parted;
Hard her heart as lunch-room pies,
While mine smarted;
Cold as bottles from the icebox !
Me she drove to drink and dicebox !!
Now her dusty dollars lie
In the bank;
She is lovely still, and I
Am a tank;
And her cash I might be spending!
Isn't this a sorry ending?
—Montingside.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
UNIVERSITY CHAT.

Messrs. Kalb and Fisher gave an impromptu exhibition of the pancratium in
Latin Major class room one morning last
week, which, idiomatically translated, means
that they wiped the floor up with each other.
The effect was heightened by the unexpected
entrance of Dr. Smith in the middle of the
second round. A very red necktie was the
exciting cause.
The cage is already credited with two accidents. Edward Spilman ('99) sprained his
ankle and was confined to his room for a week.
Marsden Smith ('98) was hurt while playing
the juvenile game of caddy and was obliged
to take a vacation.

THE NEWS-LETTER staff has received copies
of the photograph taken for The Hullabaloo.
At the Oratorio Society's concert Thursday
one could not have thrown a stone without
hitting a member of the faculty. President
Gilman, Dean Griffin, Professor Gildersleeve
and Professor Greene were all conspicuously
bunched in one corner of the hall.
The preliminary examination of all graduate students who intend to take the degree of
doctor of philosophy this year began last
week.
Dr. F. M. Warren of Adelbert College delivered the first of a series of lectures on "The
Romantic School of French Poetry." He lectured to a large audience in the Donovan
Room, his subject being "Jean Jacques Rousseau."
Dr. Harry C. Jones of the chemical department has opened a new course to graudates.
It will be devoted to the study of electrochemistry, or the study of those changes in
the composition of substances which come
about through the action of electricity in one
way or another.

HORACE.

LIB. IV., CARM. VII.
Fled are the snows, and to the meadow now
Returns the grass, the blossom to the bough.
Between their banks the brooks receding
glide ;
Earth rolls her seasons round ; each Grace,
allied
With nymphs and sister Graces, naked dares
To lead the dances forth ; airs, western airs,
Temper the cold ; now swiftly Summer nigh
Down tramples Spring, herself about to die,
When Autumn, bearing fruit, pours forth her
store ;
Next lifeless Winter visits Earth once more.
Each hour that loots the joyous day, each year
Warns not to hope for life immortal here.
Swiftly the moons their loss in heaven repair,
But we, alas ! when we have fallen where
Aeneas, our sire, rich Tullus, Ancus fell,
Shadow and dust are we. Ah ! who can tell
If to our present finished day be given
Another morrow by the gods in heaven?
All that hath blessed your happy soul will fly
Your heir's close clutch, but you, when once
you die,
stately
Minos shall assign your lot,
When
Caste, then Torquatus, will avail you not,
Nor wit, nor worth. Not from hell's gloom
could she,
Diana, pure Hippolytus set free ;
Nor might the strength of Theseus burst the
chain
Of Death from Pirithous beloved in vain.
CARL WIGHT.

MY LOVE.
Loved one, so dear to me,
Wert thou but near to me,
My love I'd own.
Far away though thou be,
Thoughts sweet shall be to thee
By some wind blown.
Live, then, in certainty,
Loved shalt thou ever be,
Ne'er left alone.

C. M. S.

O'REILLY'S ELIXIR OF LIFE.
[Being an Authentic Account of the Greatest Discovery of
the Century.]

William Henry James O'Reilly
Was a scientist of note.
He was known the whole world over
By the able books he wrote.
Why, his monograph on why the
Tails of cats are without eyes
Filled all lands with consternation,
With amazement and surprise.
Was he satisfied to linger
O'er the laurels he had won?
.Should ambition cease its soaring,
• When its flight had just begun ?
No! The goal of his desires
Was but bounded by the stars!
So as hard as ever William
Henry worked among his jars.

No. 9

Or that, rather, all who took it
(How the news rang in their ears I)
Would be younger than they were before
By five-and-twenty years.
Lean and sour-visaged spinsters
Who had passed full two-score, ten,
Took his mixture by the bottle
And were gay young girls again.
"Pore an' lonely widder ladies"
Almost lost their heads from joy.
They imbibed it by the gallon
And again were maidens coy.
Widowers with five wives buried
Hemmed and hawed, and said that they
Had no very strong objections
To continue on their way.
While the bachelors in hundreds
Could be seen at each drug store.
There was not a man among'em
But who took a case or more.

Worked! Why never in the history
Of mankind was there known
Such untiring activity
As that which he had shown.
He forgot to eat ; forgot to sleep ;
(Forgot to pay his rent.)
When at last his work was over
Then the news was broadcast sent.

Jimmie Jones—how can I tell it I —
Saw a bottle on a shelf—
Took it down and took a swallow,
And no longer was himself,
And that night when all the family
Sat o'erwhelmet1 with grief and fears,
In their midst a whisper sounded :
"Will be back in fifteen years."

Cities thrilled with mad excitement ;
Men discussed it on the cars ;
Papers spoke of it by pages.
It was telegraphed to Mars.
Exultation seized the people ;
Loud rejoicing filled the air ;
Till Professor James O'Reilly's
Hat grew too small for his hair.

Everything was topsy-turvy;
Naught was as it used to be.
You would find a mother's daughter
Who was older far than she.
Fathers, turned to beardless striplings,
Were more youthful than their sons.
Ah, through what a maze of marvels
This most truthful history runs!

For the wily James O'Reilly
Had discovered, it was said,
An elixir which would almost
Bring to life again the dead ;

Young folks had no show whatever.
These"made-over" beaux and belles
Took things firmly by the handle
And ran all to suit themselves.

2

THE NEWSLETTER.
Some young men who got disgusted
With such life, just stepped aside ;
Took a nip—evaporated!
Fin de siecle suicide.
I could tell to you forever
Of the marvels that were wrought;
Of the wondrous and astounding things
Which thus to pass were brought.
But I have a fear that someone
(Who don't know me)'11 say that I
Am just verging into danger
Of relating you a lie.
HERBERT KAUFMAN.

THE LEVERING LECTURES.

The Levering lectures are the gift of Mr.
Eugene Levering of Baltimore, the founder of
of the University Y. M. C. A. They are given
under the auspices of the Association in Levering Hall, and are intended specially for the
students of the University. They are not sermons, but they must be on topics distinctively
religious. The course has been in existence
since 1890 and now presents quite a respectable list of eminent men. They are :
1890. Rev. Dr. John A. Broadus of Southern
Baptist Theological Seminary.
1891. President W. R. Harper of Chicago
University.
1892. Rev. Dr. Richard R. Storrs of Brooklyn.
1893. Rev. Dr. William R. Huntington of
New York.
1894. President David J. Hill of the University of Rochester.
1895. Professor William R. Ramsey of the
University of Glasgow.
1896. Bishop J. H. Vincent of the M. E.
Church.
1897. Rev. Dr. Lyman Abbott of Brooklyn.
Francis Landley Patton, D. D., LL. D., the
lecturer for this year, was born in Bermuda in
1843. He received his education in Canada,
was actively engaged as a Presbyterian minister for sixteen years, and taught in the Pres-

byterian Theological Seminary at Chicago,
and later at Princeton. He was for three
years editor of The Interior, a leading Presbyterian paper published at Chicago. He became President of the College of New JersgY,
now Princeton University, in 1888, which
office he now holds.

GEOLOGICAL SPECIFIENS.

The Geological Department has just received a series of large specimens of massive
and crystallized albite, through the kindness
of Mr. W. Robinson Molinard of this city.
These specimens were taken from a large mica
mine situated about one mile north of Amelia
Courthouse, Amelia County, Va., where they
were found in a large geode during the working of the mine. They represent only a small
part of the mineral "pocket" which carried
iron pyrites, mica, garnets, corundum, fluorite
and different varieties of feldspar.
This particular "pocket," in which the albite
occurred projecting into the cavity in well-individualized crystals, is only a local development in a large lens of feldspar approximately
125 inches long by 20 inches wide, which
itself is very much like the pegmatite dikes
that are so well exposed about Baltimore, especially in the neighborhood of Orange
Grove.
The different crystals of the specimens often
show marked milky coloring or the iridescent
play of colors, which increases the value of the
specimens. The various crystals have not
been studied, but will no doubt serve as a subject of investigation for some member of the
Geological Department.

THE NEWS-LETTER was very much flattered
a short time ago by a request from a girls'
school for a copy of our paper as a model for
one they are preparing to issue. Bless them,
we wish them all the luck in the world, and
hope ere long to get some valuable points
from them !

NEWS OF A FORTNIGHT.
SENATE.

The Senate is busily preparing for forensic
battle, under the skilled leadership of the Censor, who has gained his experience in actual
contests in days gone by. A mock fight during
the last assembly served to display the valor of our stoutest champions. Their brilliant conduct on the field of "Liberty and
Equality" found its reward in the promotion
to higher honors. The general has placed in
their hands the banner of the Senate, to be
carried through the lines of the House in irresistible onslaught—or else to be covered with
the bodies of the defendants. Six Senators
are the champions-elect, viz: Senators Fisher
(leader), Stearns (secretary of war), Hubner,
Ulman, Ballard and Dieffenbach. A ministry
of war is planning the campaign, and training
the men. It consists of Senators Hodges
' (chief), Kennard (secretary) and Clarke. At
the next meeting of the Senate Champions
Fisher and Hubner will appear in a rotary
turret of points on the immigration question.
As they are confident that the missiles of fourteen assailants cannot penetrate this structure,
they will stay content with peeping at the
enemy through the loopholes.
HOUSE.

The House of Representatives met Wednesday, February 2. Mr. Censor made a few important announcements pertaining to the joint
debate. In brief, he said that the question
selected for the joint debate, "Resolved, That
further immigration to the United States
should be restricted," would be debated for
three consecutive meetings in the House ;
that two of the six selected debaters would
present points for the affirmative side, while
the House would argue against these and present additional points. The board of advisers
will record points brought forward by the
House.
At. the next session Speaker French and
Congressman Fisher will present points on
the affirmative, and one-third of the House

will argue against them. This method, as it
will be very general and searching, is practically for the purpose of getting the attitude of
the class as a whole toward the question.
The regular debate was : "Resolved, That
all men are free and equal." The affirmative
side was presented by Congressmen Knapp,
Bruce and Raymond; the negative by Congressmen Kurrelmeyer, Wright and RobinThe debate was quite lacking in dash
and spirit. The preparation that the debaters
gave the question was far too little for them
to arrive at any clear and definite idea of the
subject matter. This confusion of ideas was
also quite apparent in the open discussion.
The negative side won the debate through a
little better presentation, though no superiority of arguments.
The debaters from the class of '99 and the
advisers have taken active steps in preparation
for the joint debate. They are holding frequent meetings, in which they discuss the
question and criticise each other's style of
delivery.
The class of '99 met Wednesday, February
2. The class history was read and a few important points discussed.

THE STUDENT VOLUNTEER CONVENTION.

A notable event in inter-collegiate affairs
for this month will be the Student Volunteer
Convention, which will be held at Cleveland,
Ohio, beginning February 23. These conventions are held once in a generation of students and are attended by delegates from all
the colleges and universities of the country.
Unusual interest is being shown this year, and
the convention will be the largest ever held.
Four hundred institutions will be represented
by between 1,5oo and 2,000 students. Mr. F.S.
Brockman, Traveling Secretary of the Student Volunteer Movement, addressed the Y.
M. C. A. at its last meeting and urged that
Hopkins be well represented. The Secretary
announces that we will be represented by at
least two delegates.

The house-warming to be given on Thursday night in celebration of the opening of the
new cage and gymnasium, should be well supported by all members of the University. The
expenses of the occasion are to be met by the
undergraduate body, who will act as the hosts.
All men connected with the University are invited, and it is to be hoped that many of them
will attend. The "new era in our athletics,"
so much talked of and prophesied, could not
be better inaugurated than by making this occasion a great success. It is especially desirable that the men from the Medical School,
whose connection with the rest of the University is figuratively as well as literally "remote,"
should be well represented ; and to them in
particular a most cordial invitation is extended.

At last! Despite his anxious fears, the senior
has been rewarded. The hard-fought battles
of his freshman and junior years have not been
in vain ! He has seen his desire upon his
enemy
How he did enjoy it, with mouth and eyes

all open 1 And even the imperturbable grad.
was seen to smile a faint smile before turning
to his book again. The elevator boy's eyes
shone, and the postman waxed reminiscent.
The whole University seemed on the eye of
doing something, and the Dean
It was a noble fight, a royal scrap, a—but
words fail us. We all know just what it was,
and we all enjoyed it. What could have been
more deliriously exhilarating than to watch
that squirming mass of arms and legs? What
matters it if a few cheeks or shirts were torn,
a few hats or ribs stove in, a few buttons or
temper lost ? Think first of the pleasures it
gave; of the bookworn student who had not
had a hearty laugh since Christmas — then
strike the balance.
We must confess that we thought the old
pot social something of a failure. There was
the same wild abandon, the same noble heroism, the same melodramatic effect. But who
saw it? Only a few lucky seniors, pinned
close against the walls of a stuffy locker-room.
It was a purely selfish institution, born to crush
unseen and waste its rudeness on the dusty air.
Its sphere was too limited. It lacked a raison
d'art'. It gave pleasure to no one—except,
perhaps, the tailor.
But it's different now. We have an amphitheatre big enough for a bull-fight. There is
room for all the University, and half the town
besides. Send the faculty a special invitation
and let the ladies have reserved seats. Then
charge an admission fee for all the rest, and the
coffers of the Athletic Association will overflow.
It would be by far the most popular show in
town. And why? Is it because we are barbarous enough to hunger for the sight of
blood. Not at all. We would not have a single man hurt. We only feel more intensely
that same sense of delight which the immortal
Puck must have experienced that midsummer
night when he exclaimed : "Lord ! What
fools these mortals be !"

their effect upon mortality. We are assured
that some sweet day all doors will slam to a
set tune, and rumbling drays will sing a lullaby. However that may be, it occurs to us
that an investigation of the effect of noises
upon mentality at this University might prove
interesting. We have the finest general assortment of noises to be found anywhere in the
city. Our own little Ross street enjoys an
enviable reputation for its storminess and consequent popularity among all the drivers in
town. Car-gongs, mingled with street cries
galore, show no respect for Greek syntax or
economics? But, in addition to all these, we
take pleasure in announcing that a new noise
is in our midst. One of our neighbors to the
west has stocked his back yard with a lusty
flock of geese, and these sacred birds can reproduce at any time of the day all the "atmosphere" or "local coloring" the classical students can desire, who wishes to bring back the
time when Rome was so miraculously preserved.
THE NEWS-LETTER here solemnly promises
that it will devote its first earnings to the
purchase and exportation of those geese, and
then, if anything is left, it may think about cementing Ross street.

PROF. RILEY'S SUCCESS.

Among the recent Hopkins graduates who
have already achieved distinction is Dr. F. L.
Riley, professor of history at the University of
Mississippi. Since taking his degree here in
1896, Dr. Riley has been very energetic in his
efforts to promote the study of history in Mississippi, atld has endeavored, by addresses and
by articles in the newspapers and magazines,
to increase the interest of the public at large in
the subject. He served as secretary of the recent State Historical Association and took a
very prominent part in the proceedings of that
body. Dr. Riley is now trying to secure financial assistance from the State to publish the
papers, etc., of the Association.
About thirty of the graduate students in
chemistry enjoyed a trip to the Maryland
Steel Works at Sparrows' Point on Friday,
January 28. Dr. Charles L. Reese took the
boys down, and, with the assistance of Mr.
Reese, his brother, who is superintendent of
the works, explained the workings of the big
machinery.
All the fellows enjoyed the trip immensely
and both Dr. Reese and Mr. Reese have the
warmest thanks of those who were fortunate
enough to be able to accept their kindness.

The Universities of Indian Territory, Arizona, Honolulu and Sacarappa have adopted
the following regulations :
We can run ourselves without these little
colleges and high schools like Harvard and
Yale interfering.
No man shall play on the same team with
his grandson.
Children under five shall not be eligible for
college football teams.
Games in which we are licked shall be called
practice games.
Summer ice-polo shall be discouraged.
Rough football shall be stopped by ruling
out any player who touches another.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
ATHLETICS.
OPENING OF THE CAGE.

A large body of students, professors and
alumni listened to the speeches at the official
opening of the new gymnasium and cage.
President Gilman, Mr. Morton Stewart, Dr.
Renouf, the Dean, Dr. Read, Mr. Morrison,
Mr. Maddren and Mr. Scholl ('98) all spoke
on subjects pertaining to some feature of
physical development. The most noteworthy
speeches were beyond a doubt those of Dr.
Renouf, the director of the gymnasium, and
Mr. Morrison, the well-known lawyer and
Hopkins alumnus. They dwelt on the past
history of Hopkins athletics, and of gymnasium work in particular. It is well known
among all the students that fraternity rivalry
made the gymnasium unfashionable and
ruined our teams. Compulsory gymnasium
work will create a broader college spirit
through bringing all the students in closer
communication.
This first step towards
breaking,up our clanishness will also be the
dawn of a new and more prosperous era for
our athletics. Dr. Read gave an interesting
talk on mountain climbing, in which he called
attention to the fact that most of the noted
mountaineers are or have been university
men. Mr. Maddren spoke in the interest of
the lacrosse team, pleading for strict obedience to the captain.

CINDER TRACK NEEDED.

It is quite necessary that a cinder track
should be put in the cage. The candidates
for the track team cannot be properly trained
without it.
This track (as was stated by someone who
has experience in such matters) can be completed inside of seven days. It will not interfere with baseball or lacrosse, as it will be but
five feet broad ; on the other hand, it will afford opportunity for members of the above
mentioned teams to exercise their leg muscles
and get some wind.

HOCKEY.

The hockey team was defeated Tuesday of
last week by the University of Maryland. This
defeat puts Hopkins in third place, and makes
her chances for winning the championship
rather slim. The game was rough, several
men on both sides receiving bad cuts. Hopkins showed a decided lack of team work and
put up a slow game. The final score was :
University of Maryland 2, Johns Hopkins
University o.

ATHLETIC NOTES.

Mr. William M. Mackdermott has kindly
consented to train the track team. Mr. Mackdermott has had much experience, both as a
runner and trainer, and good results may be
looked for from this branch of athletics.
The gymnasium was opened Monday last.
Freshmen will be compelled to attend Dr.
Crenshaw's classes on Mondays, Wednesdays
and Fridays, and a record of attendance will
be kept. Tuesday and Thursdays are the days
appointed for seniors and juniors.
The class of '98, at a meeting held last Friday, decided to immortalize itself by placing
andirons in the fire-place of the smokingroom and a class shield on the wall. Messrs.
Fowler, V. E. Smith and Ulman were appointed a committee, with full power to make the
selections and assess the class the amount necessary for the purchases. Messrs. Ballard,
Harwood and Hodges were elected to the
House Committee of the gymnasium.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
THE GArIE OF GOLF.

The game of golf differs in so many essential
characteristics from other outdoor games that
at first sight it does not recommend itself to
the inter-collegiate athlete. In the first place,
unless a spectator has some personal interest
in a match, or is himself an enthusiast, golf is a
very slow game to watch. This would not suit
the average college "rooter." Again, the
rules absolutely forbid any noise—that is, talking, etc., during a stroke. College yells, which
have become a part and parcel of inter-collegiate games, would, therefore, have to be
abandoned. Further, golf differs from most
games in the fact that there is no personal contact, and consequently no man-to-man rivalry.
This would do away with the rigorous training
now so generally in vogue, as physical
strength per se is of no particular advantage,
but skill is the important factor. Many a time
have I seen some stalwart footballer, or cricketer, downed on the links by a man perhaps old
enough to be his father, or, again, by some slip
of a boy, simply because of the same skill.
It is often asked: "What is the attraction
about golf ?
Volumes could be written on
this subject. Perhaps our answer might be,
the fascination of hidden difficulties, the apparent ease with which a skillful player swings
his club and the real difficulty of attaining that
same skill. The infinite variety, for in no two
rounds of the links is a player confronted with
the same difficulties, might also be mentioned.
But the real attraction, to my mind, is that it
takes an honest gentleman to really play and
appreciate the game. And herein lies the chief
difference between this and other games. We
Americans are so bound down by rules and
umpires and reform, etc., that generosity to an
opponent and sport for sport's sake hardly get
a chance. In a match at golf each man is his
own umpire, and if any cheating and sly shifting of the "lie" of the ball, any miscounts,
creep into the golfer's record, all interest in
the game is at once lost.
Therefore, I think that inter-collegiate golf
is a most excellent thing, and deserves the attention of all true sportsmen, inasmuch as it

7

may serve to eradicate the spirit of "win by
hook or by crook" which so pervades our
American sports.
A.J. H. U. GOLFER.

EXCHANGES.

The Minnesota Magazine for January contains a well-written article on the Johns Hopkins University. It is written from a liberal
standpoint, and gives the Hopkins full credit
for the many excellent points so well known
to all her sons.
A well-deserved tribute is paid to President
Gilman for his ability and good judgment,
which have been so powerful in making our
University what it is—the first in America.
The author gives a brief account of the
foundation of the University, and then proceeds to a statement of the broad and liberal
policy which has always characterized the
management of the Hopkins.
Altogether, the article is one most satisfactory to Hopkins men. All the advantages and
good points are brought out in a manner
highly satisfactory.
One great fault is mentioned, and that is
one we all feel. It is the lack of college spirit
in the University. How long shall Hopkins
men allow this one fault to mar every account
of the University? Men, we can remove the
one great blot if we will ! Shall we not do it?

THE NEWS-LETTER.
UNIVERSITY CHAT.

Messrs. Kalb and Fisher gave an impromptu exhibition of the pancratium in
Latin Major class room one morning last
week, which, idiomatically translated, means
that they wiped the floor up with each other.
The effect was heightened by the unexpected
entrance of Dr. Smith in the middle of the
second round. A very red necktie was the
exciting cause.
The cage is already credited with two accidents. Edward Spilman ('99) sprained his
ankle and was confined to his room for a week.
Marsden Smith ('98) was hurt while playing
the juvenile game of caddy and was obliged
to take a vacation.

THE NEWS-LETTER staff has received copies
of the photograph taken for The Hullabaloo.
At the Oratorio Society's concert Thursday
one could not have thrown a stone without
hitting a member of the faculty. President
Gilman, Dean Griffin, Professor Gildersleeve
and Professor Greene were all conspicuously
bunched in one corner of the hall.
The preliminary examination of all graduate students who intend to take the degree of
doctor of philosophy this year began last
week.
Dr. F. M. Warren of Adelbert College delivered the first of a series of lectures on "The
Romantic School of French Poetry." He lectured to a large audience in the Donovan
Room, his subject being "Jean Jacques Rousseau."
Dr. Harry C. Jones of the chemical department has opened a new course to graudates.
It will be devoted to the study of electrochemistry, or the study of those changes in
the composition of substances which come
about through the action of electricity in one
way or another.

HORACE.

LIB. IV., CARM. VII.
Fled are the snows, and to the meadow now
Returns the grass, the blossom to the bough.
Between their banks the brooks receding
glide ;
Earth rolls her seasons round ; each Grace,
allied
With nymphs and sister Graces, naked dares
To lead the dances forth ; airs, western airs,
Temper the cold ; now swiftly Summer nigh
Down tramples Spring, herself about to die,
When Autumn, bearing fruit, pours forth her
store ;
Next lifeless Winter visits Earth once more.
Each hour that loots the joyous day, each year
Warns not to hope for life immortal here.
Swiftly the moons their loss in heaven repair,
But we, alas ! when we have fallen where
Aeneas, our sire, rich Tullus, Ancus fell,
Shadow and dust are we. Ah ! who can tell
If to our present finished day be given
Another morrow by the gods in heaven?
All that hath blessed your happy soul will fly
Your heir's close clutch, but you, when once
you die,
stately
Minos shall assign your lot,
When
Caste, then Torquatus, will avail you not,
Nor wit, nor worth. Not from hell's gloom
could she,
Diana, pure Hippolytus set free ;
Nor might the strength of Theseus burst the
chain
Of Death from Pirithous beloved in vain.
CARL WIGHT.

MY LOVE.
Loved one, so dear to me,
Wert thou but near to me,
My love I'd own.
Far away though thou be,
Thoughts sweet shall be to thee
By some wind blown.
Live, then, in certainty,
Loved shalt thou ever be,
Ne'er left alone.

C. M. S.
